bibl.title: Military Orders for Jefferson Randolph Kean, January 26, 1901

div1.p: Special orders #22 specify that Kean is to travel to Washington, D.C. for an examination for promotion, and then to return to his post at Quemados, Cuba, when no longer required by the board. [Courtesy of the National Archives and Records Administration]

div1.head: Military Orders for Jefferson Randolph Kean, January 26, 1901
div1.p:
HEADQUARTERS DEPARTMENT OF CUBA,
Havana, January 26, 1901.

1. The Quartermaster's Department will provide suitable
quarters for 1st Class Sergeant John M. Turrell, Signal
Corps, U. S. Army, on duty as manager of telegraph office
at Bayamo, Cuba, and 1st Class Private Guy C. Hagerman.
Signal Corps, U. S. Army, on duty as lineman at Guantá-
namo, Cuba, at a rental not to exceed twelve (12) dollars
per month in each case, from and to include December 1,
1900, and while engaged in the performance of such duty.

2. Major Jefferson R. Kean, Surgeon U. S. Volunteers, is
hereby relieved as a member of the board of officers
convened by paragraph 9, Special Orders No. 15, current
series, these headquarters, and Major Alexander N. Stark,
Surgeon, U. S. Volunteers, is detailed in his stead.

3. In compliance with telegraphic orders from the Secre-
tary of War, Major Jefferson R. Kean, Surgeon, U. S. Vol-
unteers (Captain and Assistant Surgeon, U. S. Army),
will proceed to Washington, D. C., and report in person on
February 4, 1901, to the president of the board of officers
convened in that city for examination as to his fitness for
promotion.

When no longer required by the board, Major Kean will
return to his proper station, Quemados, Cuba.
The travel enjoined is necessary for the public service.

If there are any other sergeants on duty at that post,
who are eligible and desire the position, they will be
examined at the same time.

All applicants will be required to furnish the board with
a full statement of their enlistments, ages, whether citizens
of the United States by birth or naturalization, whether
married or single, and if they have any children, their ages
and whether they are living with them at their present
station.
The board will make a separate report in each case.

The reports will be made in full in all the particulars
mentioned in paragraphs 95 and 96 of the Regulations,
giving questions and answers, and forwarded to the
Adjutant General of the Army, through these Headquar-
ters, with as little delay as practicable.
BY COMMAND OF MAJOR GENERAL WOOD:

J. B. HICKEY,
Acting Adjutant General.
